head.title: Open, Rabbit, Open: Corkscrew With Kick

hedline.hl1: Open, Rabbit, Open: Corkscrew With Kick

abstract.p: New Rabbit corkscrew makes opening wine bottles easier; photo (S)

block.p: OPENING a bottle of wine usually entails lots of tugging at a stubborn cork that often breaks in the process. It's not surprising, considering that the standard corkscrew design (a metal worm that hooks the cork, attached to a handle to tug on) hasn't really changed in 300 years.

One great innovation was the Screwpull lever-action corkscrew, introduced in the 1980's, which could be clamped onto a bottle to prize out the cork. And now there is the Rabbit, a foolproof device that could almost be the Screwpull crossed with an OXO Good Grips gadget. And it's much less expensive than a comparable Screwpull.

OPENING a bottle of wine usually entails lots of tugging at a stubborn cork that often breaks in the process. It's not surprising, considering that the standard corkscrew design (a metal worm that hooks the cork, attached to a handle to tug on) hasn't really changed in 300 years.

One great innovation was the Screwpull lever-action corkscrew, introduced in the 1980's, which could be clamped onto a bottle to prize out the cork. And now there is the Rabbit, a foolproof device that could almost be the Screwpull crossed with an OXO Good Grips gadget. And it's much less expensive than a comparable Screwpull.

The Rabbit, which looks like its name, clamps onto the neck of a wine bottle to insert the worm directly into the center of the cork. Then, with a gentle pull of the lever, the cork pops out almost instantly. The device works only if the worm is inserted properly, which means it never mangles or breaks a cork. It works equally well on the plastic or rubber corks that are usually much harder to extract. And it can eject the cork off the worm once the bottle is open.

The mechanism itself is much the same as the Screwpull's lever model, said Riki Kane, an owner of Metrokane, which makes the Rabbit. ''We've waited 17 years for Screwpull's lever-style corkscrew patent to expire,'' she said. The designer, Ed Killduff, used cushy rubber on the handles and lever, making the corkscrew more comfortable to use.
''We tested it with all size hands and even with people who had problems with their hands,'' he said. ''We found that everyone can use this model comfortably.''
The Rabbit is $69.95 and comes with a foil cutter at Sherry-Lehman, 679 Madison Avenue (61st Street) or www.sherry-lehman.com.
